text.0: that which is wealthiest wealthy god in splendoursmost illustrious.
text.1: soma is pressed thy gladdening draught indra libations lord is this.
text.2: effectual most effectual one thine as bestowing wealth of hymns.
text.3: soma is pressed thy gladdening draught indra libations lord is this.
text.4: wherewith thou art increased in strength and conquerest with thy proper aids.
text.5: soma is pressed thy gladdening draught indra libations lord is this.
text.6: him for your sake i glorify as lord of strength who wrongeth none.
text.7: the hero indra conquering all most bounteous god of all the tribes.
text.8: those goddesses both heaven and earth revere the power and might of him.
text.9: him whom our songs increase in strength the lord of bounty swift to come.
text.10: to seat your indra i will spread abroad with power this song of praise.
text.11: the saving succours that abide in him like songs extend and grow.
text.12: a recent friend he found the skilful priest he drank and showed forth treasure from the gods.
text.13: he conquered borne by strong allshaking mares and was with farspread power his friends protector.
text.14: in course of law the sapient juice was quaffed the deities to glory turned their mind.
text.15: winning through hymns a lofty title he the lovely made his beauteous form apparent.
text.16: bestow on us the most illustrious strength ward off mens manifold malignities.
text.17: give with thy might abundant vital force and aid us graciously in gaining riches.
text.18: we turn to thee as giver liberal indra lord of the bay steeds be not thou ungracious.
text.19: no friend among mankind have we to lookto why have men called thee him who spurs the niggard.
text.20: give us not up strong hero to the hungry unharmed be we whom thou so rich befriendest.
text.21: full many a boon hast thou for men demolish those who present no gifts nor pour oblations.
text.22: as indra thundering impels the rainclouds so doth he send us store of kine and horses.
text.23: thou art of old the cherisher of singers let not the rich who bring no gifts deceive thee.
text.24: adbyaryu hero bring to mighty indrafor he is king thereofthe pressedout juices.
text.25: to him exalted by the hymns and praises ancient and modern of the singing Ṛṣis.
text.26: in the wild joy of this hath indra knowing full many a form struck down resistless vṛtras.
text.27: proclaim aloud to him the savoury soma so that the hero strong of jaw may drink it.
text.28: may indra drink this soma poured to please him and cheered therewith slay vṛtra with his thunder.
text.29: come to our sacrifice even from a distance good lover of our songs the bards supporter.
text.30: the cup whence indra drinks the draught is present the amṛta dear to indra hath been drunken.
text.31: that it may cheer the god to gracious favour and keep far from us hatred and affliction.
text.32: therewith enraptured hero slay our foemen the unfriendly maghavan be they kin or strangers.
text.33: those who still aim their hostile darts to smite us turn them to flight o indra crush and kill them.
text.34: o indra maghavan in these our battles win easy paths for us and ample freedom.
text.35: that we may gain waters and seed and offspring set thou our princes on thy side o indra.
text.36: let thy bay stallions harnessed bring thee hither steeds with strong chariot and strong reins to hold them.
text.37: strong horses speeding hither bearing thunder wellharnessed for the strong exciting potion.
text.38: beside the vat strong god stand thy strong horses shining with holy oil like waves exulting.
text.39: indra they bring to thee the strong and mighty soma of juices shed by mighty pressstones.
text.40: thou art the bull of earth the bull of heaven bull of the rivers bull of standing waters.
text.41: for thee the strong o bull hath indu swollen juice pleasant sweet to drink for thine election.
text.42: this god with might when first he had his being with indra for ally held fast the paṇi.
text.43: this indu stole away the warlike weapons and foiled the arts of his malignant father.
text.44: the dawns he wedded to a glorious consort and set within the sun the light that lights him.
text.45: he found in heaven in the third lucid regions the threefold amṛta in its close concealment.
text.46: he stayed and held the heaven and earth asunder the chariot with the sevenfold reins he harnessed.
text.47: this soma set with power within the milchkine a spring whose ripe contents ten fingers empty.
